subject: Re: [junit] Test cases size and design
msgSnippet: ... Hm, the tiles don differ in behaviour or responsibility. In fact the only difference is hidden in the static makeXyzTile methods which add roads or city
messageBody:
On Tuesday 07 May 2002 10:45, Frank Gerhardt wrote:

> Without having thougt too much about it, but maybe it would make
> sense to have different classes for the different *kinds of*
> tiles. Polymorphism could be used nicely for summing up the
> different points at the end. Just a thought.

Hm, the tiles don differ in behaviour or responsibility. In fact
the only difference is hidden in the static makeXyzTile methods
which add roads or city parts to the cards.

> If you have different levels of abstraction in one test I would
> suggest to extract the lower level stuff to a separate method.

I split the test cases in two classes. The first one tests the creation
of tiles and makes sure a left turning road really turns left and the
like.
The other class subclasses the tiloe class and tests its protected
methods trying to create illegal cards (e.g. road and city part in the
same direction).

> I guess you will need this anyway in your application. Just put
> it into the test class and if necessary refactor it to the tile
> class.
I think you are right.
I made a method returning the number of roads and cities on a tile.
This reduced test cases by 7 lines each. Looks better now.
In fact this method is likely to be needed for determinating whether a
tile can be placed in a position. If the number of roads required does
not even match the program does not have to turn the card to see it
fits in no direction.

> > Would you rely on some orientation of created tiles, e.g. assume
> > the left turning road is always constructed as from east turning to
> > south (maybe this is like the Blackbox / Whitebox discussion)?
>
> What about keeping the orientation in the board? I think the
> orientation is not so much an attribute of a tile but of the
> placement of the tile on the board.
Yes. I meant: if a makeXyz method creates a tile with a left turning
road and a city part, do you have a look at the source code creating
the tile and rely on the knowledge that the city will always be in
north and the road will always be south - west or dou you allow every
city locaction as long as the road still turns left below the city?

Robert
